==Protests==
==Protests==
  +
===Cities and regions===
  +
<!--{{expand section|More cities needed - hasn't even covered whats on the death list, or maybe just remove the section. Much of it is duplicated in the timeline entries.|February 2011|date=February 2011}}-->
  +
<!-- For instance, I added the below locations, but 5 Feb 15:00, it was moved elsewhere, which could be reasonable:
  +
In addition, there were anti-regime demonstrations on at least the 4 Feb (the âDay of Departureâ) in the towns of Suez, [[Port Said]], [[Rafah, Egypt|Rafah]], [[IsmaÃ¯lia|Ismailiya]], [[Zagazig]], [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|al-Mahalla al-Kubra]], [[Aswan]] and [[Asyut]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12371479 Obama seeks quick Egypt handover], BBC News, 5 Feb 2011</ref>
  +
-->
  +   +
; Cairo
  +
[[Cairo]] has been at the epicentre of much of the crisis. The largest protests were held in downtown [[Tahrir Square]], which was considered the protest "movementâs beating heart and most effective symbol."<ref>{{cite web|author=Al Jazeera online producer |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |title=The different shades of Tahrir - Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> On the first three days of the protests, there were clashes between the central security police and protesters and as of 28 January, police forces withdrew from most of Cairo. Citizens then formed neighbourhood watch groups to keep the order as widespread looting was reported. Traffic police were reintroduced to Cairo on the morning of 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
; Alexandria
  +
[[Alexandria]], the home of [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Saeed]], had major protests and clashes against the police. Demonstrations continued and one on 3 February was reported to include 750,000 people.<ref>Al Jazeera news, 3 February 2011, approx 14:00 GMT</ref> There were few confrontations as not many Mubarak supporters were around, except in occasional motorized convoys escorted by police. The breakdown of law and order, including the general absence of police on the streets, continued through to at least the evening of 3 February, including the looting and burning of one the country's largest shopping centres.<ref>Reported by [[Wyre Davies]] of the [[BBC News]], 3 Feb 2011, approx 19:00 GMT</ref> Alexandria protests were notable for the presence of Christians and Muslims jointly taking part in the events following the church bombing on 1 January.<ref name="aljazlive" />
  +   +
; Mansoura
  +
In the northern city of [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansoura]] there were protests against the Mubarak regime every day from 25 January onwards. One protest on 1 February was estimated at one million people,<ref>Al Jazeera exclusive TV report, first broadcast 3 Feb 2011, 13.30 GMT</ref> while on 3 February, 70,000 people were reported on the streets.<ref>Stated by Professor Mohamed Ghoneim, interviewed on Al Jazeera, 3 Feb 2011, approx 19:30 GMT</ref>
  +   +
; Siwa
  +
The remote city of [[Siwa Oasis|Siwa]] has thus far been reported as relatively calm.<ref name="Sterling">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/03/egypt.protests.anxiety/|title=Across dusty Egypt, anxiety has filled the air|last=Sterling|first=Joe|date=February 4, 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> Local [[sheikhs]], who were reportedly in control of the community, put the community under [[lockdown]] after a nearby town was "[[Arson|torched]]."<ref name="Mistry">{{cite news|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/8823127.Family__cut_off__amid_Egypt_riots/|title=Mother from St. Albans Speaks to the Review from Egypt|last=Mistry|first=Manisha|publisher=''[[St. Albans Review]]'' (part of [[Newsquest]])|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
; Suez
  +
The city of [[Suez]] has seen the most violence of the protests thus far. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com">{{cite web|last=Tencer|first=Daniel|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/|title=Reports of 'Massacre' in Suez as Protests in Egypt Move into Third day|work=[[The Raw Story]]|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], the Tunisian city where protests started.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> A labour strike was held on 8 February.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2 "As Egypt Protest Swells, U.S. Sends Specific Demands"] ''The New York Times'' - Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> Large protests took place on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref>
  +   +
; Luxor
  +
There were also protests in [[Luxor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ |title=Egypt Travel Advice |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
; Sinai Peninsula
  +
[[Bedouins]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] fought the security forces for several weeks.<ref>{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protests Swell in Rejection of Egyptâs Limited Reforms|date=February 8, 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=February 8, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
; Sharm-El-Sheikh
  +
No protests or civil unrest took place in [[Sharm-El-Sheikh]] on 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stevenson, Rachel|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/31/egypt-sharm-el-sheikh-tourists-tension|title=Sharm El-Sheikh's Tourists Talking About a Revolution|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> All was still calm as Hosni Mubarak and his family left on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +   +
; Deirout
  +
Police opened fire on protesters in the [[Deirout]] near the southern suburbs of [[Cairo]] and [[Asyut]], on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +   +
; Shebin el-Kom
  +
Tens of thousands protester took to the streets of [[Shebin el-Kom]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +   +
; El-Arish
  +
Thousands protested in the city of [[El-Arish]], in the Sinai Penisular on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +
[[File:Egy sag.png|thumb|Protesters removing portraits of Ex-president Mubarak in Sohag City in upper Egypt]]
  +   +
; Sohag
  +
Large protests took place in the southern city of [[Sohag]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +   +
; Minya
  +
Large protests took place in the southern city of [[Minya, Egypt|Minya]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +   +
; Ismailia
  +
Nearly 100,000 people protested in and about the local government headquarters in [[Ismailia]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  +

====26 January====
+
=====26 January=====
On 26 January riots continued, with protesters numbering in the thousands, although no accurate estimate has yet been made. There was increased use of violence from both protesters and the police, with one protester and one police official killed in Cairo.<ref name="np26jan" /> Suez experienced a dramatic uprising; many protesters were fired upon with live ammunition, and both protesters and police were beaten. Protesters in Suez also managed to set fire to several government buildings, including the police station.<ref name="np26jan">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/More+casualties+protests+escalate+Egypt/4173057/story.html|title=More Casualties as Protests Escalate in Egypt|work=[[National Post]]|date=22 December 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera-448">{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police post|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112617427113878.html|title=Clinton Calls for reform in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
On 26 January riots continued, with protesters numbering in the thousands, although no accurate estimate has yet been made. On the night of 30 January Mubarak's [[Sharm el-Sheikh]] holiday villa was guarded by a small force of armed and loyal police who turned away all approaching vehicles.<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8290760/Locals-in-Sharm-el-Sheikh-convinced-Mubarak-is-holed-up-there.html|title=Locals in Sharm-el-Sheikh convinced Mubarak is holed up there}}</ref> Sharm el-Sheikh had seen no deaths and only a minimal amount of trouble.<ref name="telegraph1" /> A number of [[military aircraft]] were visible from the local airportâs perimeter fence, although the airport is frequently used by the armed forces for operations.<ref name="telegraph1" /> It was also one of the hubs for private air travel in and around Egypt, but most [[light aircraft]] had left the airport earlier in the day.<ref name="telegraph1" />

====31 January====
+
=====31 January=====
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.

====11 February â Farewell Friday ====
+
=====11 February â Farewell Friday =====
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named "Farewell Friday" by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1"/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>{{-}}
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named "Farewell Friday" by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1"/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>{{-}}
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazlive" /> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazlive" />

===== 12 February =====
[[file:People celebrating the fall of Mubarak.ogg|thumb|People celebrating on the streets of Cairo]]A group of activists issued what they called the "People's CommuniquÃ© No 1", imitating the titles of communiquÃ©s from the Army. It demanded the dissolution of the cabinet Mubarak had appointed on 29 January; the suspension of the parliament elected late last year in a poll widely suspected of rigging; the creation of a transitional five-member presidential council made up of four civilians and one military person; the formation of a transitional government to prepare for an election to take place within nine months, and of a body to draft a new democratic constitution; freedom for the media and syndicates, which represent groups such as lawyers, doctors and engineers, and for the formation of political parties; and the scrapping of military and emergency courts. They announced the formation of a council to call and call off mass protests. <ref name="reuterscomm1">[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/12/us-egypt-protesters-idUSTRE71B17Q20110212 Egypt protest leaders vow to protect revolution]. Andy Roberts DARnet. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011.</ref>. The hours of [[curfew]] were reduced to between [[midnight]] and 6:00 Cairo local time.<ref name="aljazeera5">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/11/live-blog-feb-12-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 12 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>

==== 14 February ====
+
===== 14 February =====
Two representatives from the demonstrators, [[Wael Ghonim]] and [[Amr Salama]], met with spokespersons of the military and reported that there would be a [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum on changes to the constitution]] within two months.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 9 hours ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=AFP: Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
Two representatives from the demonstrators, [[Wael Ghonim]] and [[Amr Salama]], met with spokespersons of the military and reported that there would be a [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum on changes to the constitution]] within two months.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 9 hours ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=AFP: Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising]</ref>

In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising]</ref>

  â   â
; Cairo
  â
[[Cairo]] has been at the epicentre of much of the crisis. The largest protests were held in downtown [[Tahrir Square]], which was considered the protest "movementâs beating heart and most effective symbol."<ref>{{cite web|author=Al Jazeera online producer |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |title=The different shades of Tahrir - Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> On the first three days of the protests, there were clashes between the central security police and protesters and as of 28 January, police forces withdrew from most of Cairo. Citizens then formed neighbourhood watch groups to keep the order as widespread looting was reported. Traffic police were reintroduced to Cairo on the morning of 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
; Alexandria
  â
[[Alexandria]], the home of [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Saeed]], had major protests and clashes against the police. Demonstrations continued and one on 3 February was reported to include 750,000 people.<ref>Al Jazeera news, 3 February 2011, approx 14:00 GMT</ref> There were few confrontations as not many Mubarak supporters were around, except in occasional motorized convoys escorted by police. The breakdown of law and order, including the general absence of police on the streets, continued through to at least the evening of 3 February, including the looting and burning of one the country's largest shopping centres.<ref>Reported by [[Wyre Davies]] of the [[BBC News]], 3 Feb 2011, approx 19:00 GMT</ref> Alexandria protests were notable for the presence of Christians and Muslims jointly taking part in the events following the church bombing on 1 January.<ref name="aljazlive" />
  â   â
; Mansoura
  â
In the northern city of [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansoura]] there were protests against the Mubarak regime every day from 25 January onwards. One protest on 1 February was estimated at one million people,<ref>Al Jazeera exclusive TV report, first broadcast 3 Feb 2011, 13.30 GMT</ref> while on 3 February, 70,000 people were reported on the streets.<ref>Stated by Professor Mohamed Ghoneim, interviewed on Al Jazeera, 3 Feb 2011, approx 19:30 GMT</ref>
  â   â
; Siwa
  â
The remote city of [[Siwa Oasis|Siwa]] has thus far been reported as relatively calm.<ref name="Sterling">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/03/egypt.protests.anxiety/|title=Across dusty Egypt, anxiety has filled the air|last=Sterling|first=Joe|date=February 4, 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> Local [[sheikhs]], who were reportedly in control of the community, put the community under [[lockdown]] after a nearby town was "[[Arson|torched]]."<ref name="Mistry">{{cite news|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/8823127.Family__cut_off__amid_Egypt_riots/|title=Mother from St. Albans Speaks to the Review from Egypt|last=Mistry|first=Manisha|publisher=''[[St. Albans Review]]'' (part of [[Newsquest]])|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
; Suez
  â
The city of [[Suez]] has seen the most violence of the protests thus far. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com">{{cite web|last=Tencer|first=Daniel|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/|title=Reports of 'Massacre' in Suez as Protests in Egypt Move into Third day|work=[[The Raw Story]]|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], the Tunisian city where protests started.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> A labour strike was held on 8 February.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2 "As Egypt Protest Swells, U.S. Sends Specific Demands"] ''The New York Times'' - Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> Large protests took place on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref>
  â   â
; Luxor
  â
There were also protests in [[Luxor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ |title=Egypt Travel Advice |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
; Sinai Peninsula
  â
[[Bedouins]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] fought the security forces for several weeks.<ref>{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protests Swell in Rejection of Egyptâs Limited Reforms|date=February 8, 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=February 8, 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
; Sharm-El-Sheikh
  â
No protests or civil unrest took place in [[Sharm-El-Sheikh]] on 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stevenson, Rachel|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/31/egypt-sharm-el-sheikh-tourists-tension|title=Sharm El-Sheikh's Tourists Talking About a Revolution|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> All was still calm as Hosni Mubarak and his family left on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  â   â
; Deirout
  â
Police opened fire on protesters in the [[Deirout]] near the southern suburbs of [[Cairo]] and [[Asyut]], on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  â   â
; Shebin el-Kom
  â
Tens of thousands protester took to the streets of [[Shebin el-Kom]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  â   â
; El-Arish
  â
Thousands protested in the city of [[El-Arish]], in the Sinai Penisular on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  â
[[File:Egy sag.png|thumb|Protesters removing portraits of Ex-president Mubarak in Sohag City in upper Egypt]]
  â   â
; Sohag
  â
Large protests took place in the southern city of [[Sohag]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  â   â
; Minya
  â
Large protests took place in the southern city of [[Minya, Egypt|Minya]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
  â   â
; Ismailia
  â
Nearly 100,000 people protested in and about the local government headquarters in [[Ismailia]] on 11 February.<ref name="signonsandiego1" />
